text:
DONALD TRUMP: I loved
my previous life.
I loved my previous life.
I had so many things going.

I actually-- this is more
work than in my previous life.
I thought it would be easier.

- Being President
of the most powerful

country in the world in
history, is actually hard work.
Who would have thunk it?

So where does President
Trump go from here?
The panel's back with me.

Senator Santorum, you
ran for president twice.

You were a senator
for many years.
What do you make of his--
the idea that he thought that--

RICK SANTORUM: Well,
this actually reminds me,

I met with Trump in
the summer of 2014.

And we talked about
my book, actually.
- Blue Collar Conservative?

RICK SANTORUM: Blue
Collar Conservative.

And he talked about that this
was something that he agreed
with and that he wanted to--

and he was sort of musing
about running for president.

And he spent about 10 minutes
telling me why his life now

would be better-- is
better than than, you
know, than being president.
- I don't doubt it.

RICK SANTORUM: And
that, you know,

he would have to really
give up something.

And I think that's
reflected here,

is that he felt like
he's given up a lot
and this job is easier.

- But why would he think
it would be easier?

RICK SANTORUM: This
job is really tough,
it's kicking his butt.

- Why would he think it would
be easier to be president

than to be host of
"Celebrity Apprentice?"

RICK SANTORUM: You
know, I think--

I'm not-- I'm not--
- You don't have to answer that.
RICK SANTORUM: I'm not too sure.

ANA NAVARRO: Well, we know
he hasn't given up golf.

He spent 20% of the
first 100 days golfing.

He did 20 golf trips, a
lot to my State of Florida,

which is really costing
us a lot of money.

- Not about 20%
of his presidency.

ANA NAVARRO: OK.
- That's fuzzy math.
But he golfed a lot.

ANA NAVARRO: He golfed
20 times in 100 days.
- OK, yeah.

ANA NAVARRO: In Trump
properties, by the way.

We know he hasn't
given up tweeting.

We know he hasn't given
up promoting his brand.
Neither has his family.

We know he hasn't given
up lying, exaggerating,
and telling mistruths.

And we know he's riding
around in a really nice plane.

He hasn't even given
up his private jet.
So what exactly has he given up?

- This is a really insightful
quote from an interview

the President did
with the Associated

Press that hasn't
gotten much attention,
and I want to read it to you.

"Here," meaning Washington,
"everything, pretty

much everything you
do in government

involves heart, whereas
in business, most
things don't involve heart.

In fact, in business,
you're actually
better off without it."

This is fascinating
that government
is about heart, business--
- Where is his heart?

Where is his heart
when he is promoting

a health care bill that
will cut off preexisting
conditions for people?

Where is his heart
in that speech

last night, which was all about
division instead of unity?

I want a President
who has heart, too.

I don't want a President
who evokes hate.

I want a President who takes us
higher and not into the gutter.

I want a President who causes
us to feel proud, all of us,
and not just a small slice.

a just very disturbing
that that heart quote

has not been brought
into the presidency.

But if he's feeling wistful
about being President,

there is a lot of us who
are also feeling wistful
about him being President.

RICK SANTORUM: Well, first
off, I don't think his speech

was that divisive last night.
I think there are a lot of--

JENNIFER GRANHOLM: You wouldn't
have given that speech, Rick.

RICK SANTORUM: I would not
have given that speech.

But a lot of the things
that he said in that speech

were things that Democrats--
JENNIFER GRANHOLM: Some of them.

RICK SANTORUM: A lot of the
things he said in that speech
were things that Democrats--
it was a populist speech.

It reached-- he's a
whole new politician.
He's not a--

JENNIFER GRANHOLM:
That snake-- come on.

Now, that snake poem where he
equates refugees with snakes,

where he equates
people who are fleeing

their country, with snakes,
I mean, that's just--

RICK SANTORUM: He equated
radical Islamic terrorists

that he is not going to
allow in this country.

JENNIFER GRANHOLM: No, no, no.
No, no.

He was talking about Syrian
refugees, women and children
who are fleeing being bombed.

RICK SANTORUM:
Keeping out terrorists
is what he was talking about.
ANA NAVARRO: Listen.

He's had-- in 100 days, he
had about two minutes of unity
in the whole 100 days.

And I will tell you,
it's when he introduced

the widow of the deceased
Navy Seal at the joint address
to Congress.

- It was a powerful
moment, no question.

ANA NAVARRO: He has
got to do more of that.

I thought-- well, I
thought yesterday was so
symbolic of the last 100 days.

And it tells me of
the next 100 days.
You had Trump in--

President Trump in Pennsylvania
speaking to his base,

feeding red meat to the
base, and being divisive.

You had the press
celebrating the press,
standing up for journalism.

And you had the
resistance marching

in sweltering heat in
Washington for climate change
and against Trump.

Folks, that's what the
last 100 days has been?

That's what the next 1,360
days are going to be.
- Or if not longer.
There's a bit of controversy--
ANA NAVARRO: Oh, God, don't.
- Well, who can beat him?
RICK SANTORUM: That's right.

- Tell me who's
going to beat him.

A bit of controversy
broke out this week
on the Democratic side.

We learned that President
Obama has agreed

to accept $400,000,
that's one year's

worth of presidential
salary, to speak in September
at a Wall Street conference.

Senator Elizabeth Warren
said she was troubled by it.
And Bernie Sanders also did.
Take a listen.

BERNIE SANDERS: I think it
just does not look good.
It's not a good idea.

And, you know, I'm sorry
that the President--

President Obama
made that choice.
He's a private citizen.
I just think it is distasteful.
- Is it distasteful to you?
VAN JONES: It's not distasteful.

I do think that he
started off talking
to those kids in Chicago.

And we need a Bobby
Kennedy in this country.

And I hope that he will do
a tour, go to Appalachia,

go to Native
American reservations

where they're shoving these
pipelines down their throats

and they don't even have
clean running water.
Go to South Central.

Go to the Arizona border where
you have a lot of poverty.

If he were to do a
poverty tour first--

listen, he should not
be the first president
that has to be broke.

Listen, every other
president went out

there and gave big
speeches, don't
hold them to a second standard.

Don't give a double
standard to him.

But I tell you what, from
a moral point of view,

it would be great for
him to do [inaudible].

- He signed a $60
million book deal.
I mean, he's not broke.
VAN JONES: Exactly.

- No, but I mean, like--
listen.
Listen.

Do you not think he was
elected, to a degree,

to fight the forces
on Wall Street?

VAN JONES: Sure and
he's done with that.
- Clearly.

VAN JONES: If I
were-- if I were--

if I had the
opportunity that he has,

I would do a big poverty
tour for six months.

Everywhere I go, it's
poverty, addiction,

and high death rates, from
West Virginia to South Central.

And if he would do that,
then, yeah, go ahead
and do a big speech later.

JENNIFER GRANHOLM: I would
like to see every Democrat do

a tour like that
where they really

are looking into
the eyes of people
who were terribly hurting.

But I would say I'd
like to see more--

I mean, he's not
in office anymore.

He's not running
for office anymore.

- But this is one of the
first things he's doing,

a $400,000 speech to
Cantor Fitzgerald.

JENNIFER GRANHOLM:
I mean, and so has--

I mean, George Bush, when he
left, he gave a big speech,
and you know, he gets $200,000.

I'm much more interested
in those who are coming up.

And I'm also much more
outraged that, for example, we

have a president
who is profiting off

of being in office, doubling
the amount of money people

are paying for ownership
in his club or membership
to his club, $200,000 now.
He doubled the price.

Making sure that,
you know, he says

he's in a blind trust,
all of the conflicts
that we've heard about.

That, to me, is
much more outrageous

when you have a sitting
president who's profiting
a lot more [inaudible].

ANA NAVARRO: Man, that's
a masterful pivot, man.

- Quickly--
VAN JONES: I love this one--

- That was good.
VAN JONES: I love this one.
What she said.
- Yeah, I know, that's a--

JENNIFER GRANHOLM:
But it's true.
Aren't you more mad about that?
- Olympic judging--

JENNIFER GRANHOLM: You should
be more mad about that.
- She gets a 10.

JENNIFER GRANHOLM: He's
not making policies.

RICK SANTORUM: We have
two high-profile Democrats

who are concerned
about President Obama

and thinking about
what President

Obama should be doing
because they have no leaders

in that party anymore.
- I think that's true.

RICK SANTORUM: That's
the real problem.

And they're relying upon
him to get their message--

JENNIFER GRANHOLM: That is not
true that there are no leaders.
There are lots--

- I think the problem is
there's no leader right now.

JENNIFER GRANHOLM: Right,
because we're not in power.
- There's no singular leader.
We've got to go.

Thank you one and all,
except for Van Jones.
